spanishExample: *¿How much* tiempo *do you want to spend* aquí?
englishTranslation: How much time do you want to spend here?

spanishExample: Ella ha sido una buena amiga.
englishTranslation: She has been a good friend.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Esa vez que estuvo en mi casa.
englishTranslation: That time that he was at my house.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Esta vez he sido una buena chica.
englishTranslation: This time I have been a good girl.
vocabIncluded: he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Este *man* y esa *woman* han estado aquí.
englishTranslation: This man and that woman have been here.
vocabIncluded: han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Este no ha estado aquí por un tiempo.
englishTranslation: This one(m) hasn’t been here for a while.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Esto ha estado aquí por días.
englishTranslation: This has been here for days.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

englishTranslation: She has been here one time.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

englishTranslation: It has been a good day.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Haber *gone* sería bueno, pero no ha *gone.*
englishTranslation: To have gone would be good, but she hasn’t gone.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
haber: "to have", "having" before a participle (Haber, infinitive)
sería: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Ser, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Haber sido su amiga era bueno.
englishTranslation: Having been her friend(f) was good.
vocabIncluded: haber: "to have", "having" before a participle (Haber, infinitive)

englishTranslation: They have come from the place I mentioned.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
del: "of the" before a masculine noun
han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Han estado aquí por un tiempo.
englishTranslation: They have been here for a while.
vocabIncluded: han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

englishTranslation: They have been here.
vocabIncluded: han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

englishTranslation: They have had this thing.
vocabIncluded: han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

englishTranslation: You have been at this place.
vocabIncluded: has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

englishTranslation: You have been at the house.
vocabIncluded: has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

englishTranslation: You have been a good guy.
vocabIncluded: has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

englishTranslation: I have been here.
vocabIncluded: he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: He estado en ese lugar una vez.
englishTranslation: I have been at that place one time.
vocabIncluded: he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

englishTranslation: I have been your friend(m).
vocabIncluded: he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

englishTranslation: We have been at the place.
vocabIncluded: hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Hemos estado en ese lugar por un tiempo.
englishTranslation: We have been at that place for a while.
vocabIncluded: hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)

englishTranslation: We have had a lot of time.
vocabIncluded: hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)

englishTranslation: We have had the things since that day.
vocabIncluded: hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)

englishTranslation: We have been good friends(f).
vocabIncluded: hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: *I want* estar aquí por *a long* tiempo.
englishTranslation: I want to be here for a long time.
The girls have been friends.
vocabIncluded: han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

englishTranslation: Not this time.
You have not eaten that one (f).
vocabIncluded: has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

englishTranslation: I have not been here.
vocabIncluded: he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: No *he had* tiempo, pero hemos *had work.*
englishTranslation: I haven’t had time, but we have had work.
vocabIncluded: hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: No *you’re going* al lugar *where* estuve esa vez.
englishTranslation: You aren’t going to the place where I was that time.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun

spanishExample: *Nobody needs* haber estado en ese lugar.
englishTranslation: Nobody needs to have been at that place.
vocabIncluded: haber: "to have", "having" before a participle (Haber, infinitive)

englishTranslation: You(formal) have been here.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment

spanishExample: Usted ha *had enough* tiempo en esta casa.
englishTranslation: You(formal) have had enough time at this house.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment

spanishExample: Yo *want* esa casa, pero tú has *wanted* esta.
englishTranslation: I want that house, but you have wanted this one(f).
vocabIncluded: has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)
